text: A friend/colleague of mine brought up a really good question to me that I couldn’t answer (which doesn’t actually say much—I’m not very knowledgable).  There is a lot of talk about the M1 chip, and Julia “natively” supporting that chip.  But this is what I (and my friend) don’t understand: if natively supporting the chip means having its own set up CPU instructions that Julia knows how to interact with, why is this Julia’s job to support the chip?  Why is this not handled by LLVM—does LLVM not come at that low level where it is interacting with the M1 chip?

text: Well... LLVM optimizations and passes sometimes get a lot slower. Just like GCC it's mainly tuned to generating fast code, not to producing that code very fast. As such, Julia's usecase might not get the most attention

text: It is a combination of the hardware platform, ARM64 as well as the Operating System being macOS. macOS on ARM64 doesn't have Fortran and BLAS as far as I know other than the BLAS that Apple supplies through their Accelerate Framework. Julia depends on BLAS. Why Julia doesn't use BLAS from Accelerate, I am not sure of, but those are the kinds of issues that pop up in supporting M1.
